description:
SERVICE - 4/5
The lady was nice.  At least we were charged correctly for what we ordered.

FOOD: - 
- Beef Siu Mai (Aou Yuk Siu Mai) (dumplings) - 3 for $2.40 - 5/5

- Turnip Cake (Lao Bak Go) - 3 for $2.40 - 5/5
(daikon and dried shrimp)

- Chiu Chow Dumpling (Chiu Chow Fun Gao) - 3 for $2.40 - 5/5 (peanuts, daikon, onions and pork) - 

- Rice Noodle Roll with Beef (Aw Yuk Cheurng) - 3 for $3.20 - 5/5
Good but wished that the rice noodle was more like in the dim sum tea houses which are more smooth and slippery.
author: J W.

description:
Obviously this isn't a place you would go out of your way for but if you live the area like I do, you may find yourself coming here weekly.

The prices are cheaper than the dim sum bakeries on Irving and there's a fairly wide selection. My go-to is actually the box of black bean spareribs over rice, as it comes with heapfuls of cabbage if you're here early enough (they may run out of that delicious cabbage if you show up too late). I always get it with soy sauce. It's filling and costs only $5.50 (with tax). You can also get a box of chicken feet for $5.50. Sure the spareribs and the chicken feet are fatty but that's my preference.

The dumplings are nice and glutinous although quite salty/full of MSG. I tend to prefer the cheung fan over the dumplings and also the lo mai gai (comes in small and large).

Not that this really factors into my ratings, but the people who work here are always quite pleasant! It's a welcome change from what I'm used to seeing in the Sunset.
author: Tiffany H.

description: I always come to buy 炸兩 but they always said don't want to make it. She always doesn't ask and say we don't make it. Next time when you need it calls at 8am pick up at noon. Go buy food like gambling. No manager or any owner, always travels.
author: Desmond L.

description: Rice noodle rolls, pork buns, hot dog buns are my fave here! Dim sum is good too. Line is not too long. To wait in, sometimes it's not long at all. Prices are decent not too expensive. Cash only. Make sure you come before 2pm so they don't run out of the food you want.
author: Jaxxxie P.

description: The turnip cake, small baked BBQ pork bun, and shrimp roll were all okay--nothing special. The large baked BBQ pork bun looked soggy. The dan tat was really good though--really flakey crust that wasn't too hard or soft. Will get it again and try the chicken feet next time. FYI there's also a butcher shop nearby called Cheung Hing where I got chicken feet, chicken liver, and roast duck (the chicken feet were the best).
author: Fawn B.

description: Big portions, good prices, but GREASY. Whew. I went through so many wet wipes. Steamed should not be greasy. Just saying.
author: Nini M.

description:
I come here all the time!! Love it
I have noticed so
Sometimes the prices vary... but it's worth it. Best dim sum around
author: DEANNA W.

description: The quality of food is getting worse and worse. Specially the shrimp dumplings are not fresh and smells bad.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I have lived in the neighborhood for more than 20 years and I don't come here that often.  Their shrimp and pork dumplings don't taste fresh.  But I do come here when I want to have pork porridge and Beef Cheung Fun (Rice Noodle Roll) for breakfast.  That is what I got this morning.  
Here is the disgusting part.  In the porridge, I finished 3/4 of it already, something tasted wrong.  I spit it out in the sink, it appears to be hair roll up with more disgusting things.  It looks just like the dirt ball on the mop after you clean the floor.  It feel so disgusting because I chew on it.  I immediately brush my teeth but still feel so dirty.  I don't understand how could it be mixed into that big pot of porridge.  Did they use the mop for the floor to clean the kitchen countertop?  

After this no matter what I am not going back to this place.
author: Samuel L.

description: I come here a lot, but I seriously thinking of not to come here anymore. Food is mediocre, porridge is water down. Service is slow and they serve others in the middle of your order (not once, but 3 times today). But dim sum here is inexpensive and big in portion. Sigh.
author: Apple L.

description: The food is ok  but I think tc on Irving is much better , if u do go there be ready for those lady to up sell u , like u want 1piece they make u buy 3 piece and please do your math before hand they will overcharge u , trick is speak slow and don't let them rush u . Will not come back !
author: C L.

description:
Pretty solid, pretty in-expensive Chinese/dim sum deli, meaning you can get a bunch of entries, dim sum and baked goods that are made in-house and loaded on trays to sell.

There's usually a decent line and they have good stuff. It's not the best cuisine I've had but for the price it more than gets the job done.  I usually get their pork and salted egg porridge and their Chinese doughnut along with a couple dim sum items and maybe their sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf.
author: Mike L.

description: I come here when I need a quick dim sum fix. Their food is good but not great, like I wouldn't crave their pot stickers or shrimp dumplings. They open at 7am if you have to rush off to work and need some breakfast to go. The staff are friendly and will try to upsell you during closing hours, which I think is hilarious...but it works.
author: Sam Y.

description:
Came here before I started going to TC Pastry. This place was a bit higher in price and some of the things I ordered has such a high amounts of sodium and MSG that I would often get very thirsty afterward. 

Now that TC Pastry is popping up everywhere I might need to come back here. TC Pastry multiple locations have caused a decay of quality in their foods. Turned it into the McDonald's of Dim Sum.
author: M C.

description: The food looks good but I had a bad service. She gave me my change, left my orders on the counter and walked away. I didn't know if I'm supposed to just get my orders or what!!!
author: Malou B.

description:
Love their baked small BBQ pork buns!!
It's great if you want less carbs but still want to enjoy baked BBQ pork buns.
author: Dazzler D.

description: The dim sum is not great. If I were just rating the dim sum, I may give it 3 stars, but I have to take away a star for the penalty pricing for being white. I have been there three times and literally ordered the exact same thing. Once with a Chinese speaking friend and the other two times solo. I was charged different but higher prices the two times I went in there by myself. Nothing else changed other than the fact I did not have my Chinese speaking friend with me. Sure it could be math mistakes but highly unlikely given it was just 3 orders. I will not be back
author: John D.

description:
Awesome spot for when you don't want to wait in long dimsum lines or when you want a quick dimsum fix.

The siumai is bomb. Highly recommend.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Ugh what a disappointment this place was!
I was walking my dog and I saw a huge line, so I decided to get some dim sum, once I got to the front of the line I ended up getting the beef siu mai, the shrimp rice crepe, and the chives fried dumpling.

I was really excited when I got home (i live very close by), and the food itself was cold, argggg are you kidding me??? I usually go to booming dim sum and there everything is steaming warm (too bad they got shut down).  The dim sum itself was below subpar, but I guess the price point is good.

If I'm in desperate need of s***y dim sum I'll probably come back, other than that I have no other reason for coming here.  You'd be a fool to wait in line smh.  I really wanted to like this place, hopefully it was a fluke.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Used to come when I was a kid,  back then spare ribs rice was only $3!
Over the years price increase quite alot, food taste the same though, still my favorite dim sum store in the neighborhood
author: Steven R.

description:
Hubby just picked up some dim sum to go on a Monday morning. The food was dismal.

Chives dumpling - hubby spat it out. He said it tasted days' old.
Sticky rice in lotus leaf - too much rice and scant amount of meat
Baked BBQ bun - gross! I think it was actually spoiled. The meat filling tasted vinegary. Tossed.
Steamed BBQ bun - this was actually tasty. 
Shrimp noodle roll - this was made fresh. Tasted pretty good but I prefer the noodle skin much thinner

All in all - won't be coming back. Plenty of other places to go.
author: Lisa C.

description: The dim sum here is only so so but the prices are good and it's nice to be able to see everything and decide what to get. Lines can be long at times but the ladies working here are pretty efficient. I usually get pork and preserved egg porridge, mini BBQ pork buns, and siu mei. Food can be greasy and hit or miss (like the dumpling skin can be thick), but it's really more of a low cost fast dim sum place.
author: Ellen H.

description: If you're looking for a hole in the wall dim sum spot, this is it. They have about 4 to 5 tables and each seats two. Everything on the menu was in Chinese, I think and of course I was lost . So I had 1 million questions. The lady behind the counter was really cool about it, really friendly and was more than happy to describe items to me. I walked out with some shrimp dumplings, 4 vegetable dumpling thing and two pork buns. Everything was really good, but I wish they would have been warm. I don't even know if it's supposed to be warm...
author: Juan D.

description:
I have a weakness for Dim Sum, and this is my favorite in the area. Sometimes the line gets long, but service is quick. 

There is no menu in english so it can be an adventure. Thankfully they speak enough english to understand and get your order. 

My favorites are their steamed buns - both pork and combination. The combination steamed bun is as big as my head!!!

Note: They are CASH ONLY! 

Almost every time I am in the area, I come here.
author: Nichole L.

description:
Food is great! They are not really consistent with the oil consistency. Sometimes its super oil, sometimes its too dry. Nevertheless i always come back since its 3 blocks away from my house. Its cheap! Its delicious! They have lots of options.
One barrier is the seller cant really speak english, so sometimes you have to fight to get what you want. If you come at busy hour, the seller sometimes ignores you. They also force you to choose faster. A bit scary but i am their forever customer.
author: Kallista P.

description: Watch the ladies behind the counter or you'll end up paying for food that they conveniently 'forget' to add to your order. Happened to me today.
author: Kay L.

description:
Still one of my go to spots for tasty and cheap take-out dim sum whenever I am in the neighborhood.  Definitely a hole in the wall kind of place, but you know it's good due to its popularity.

Love just about everything they make.  My favs are definitely the bao's (bbq pork buns, chicken buns, egg custard buns), shrimp dumplings, tea leaf wrapped chicken in sticky rice, green onion pastry (always sells out in morning hours), chicken feet, spare ribs, white radish  cake, hom-gok, shrimp and beef rice wrapped in rice noodle...  Think I got all my favs in there...

Very reasonable pricing.  Usually a line out the door in the morning and lunch hours.  It also helps if you speak a little bit of Chinese, but not 100% necessary.
author: Lawrence L.

description: Decent dim sum for the price.  I ate in! No English on the wall menu. She gave me 3 free dumplings with peanut and mysterious veggies and said, "don't eat outside, only inside, they dry on outside." I thought she meant they taste better in-house. Which is probably also true after a quick microwave.  Sticky rice was not bad either.  Total bill $6.40 for a full tummy. Cash only.
author: Rick W.

description:
I ask if the new staff that any "feet", she took it out but with dark grissy color kept next glass cabinet I denied with my opinion that overnight food is my impressive first feeling. 
amazingly she kept defensive and I challenged if she speaks like owner condescended manner.
whoa Never stopping altitude scare my future visit. I entered because I need a cup of coffee. bad luck. no coffee. with hk milk tea but no coffee.  my goodness.
author: Yong D.

description: Decided to check this place out given that there's always long lines on weekend mornings. I ordered three different types of rice rolls (pork, shrimp and vegetarian), their shrimp dumpling and their taro cake to give it a try. First of all, it's expensive, for all the food I ordered I paid close to $10 and it's not even high end dim sum. All this was To Go, which the lady decided to shove it all into two small boxes. The taste was below average. The shrimp was not fresh and taste very fishy. The dumpling skin was too thick and crumbly. The rice rolls were average. The taro cake was really bad, soggy and with no taro in it. The service was below average which is typical of your Chinese store. I will not come back and will not recommend.
author: Melissa C.

description:
My friend and I each ordered a plate full of various dim sum items. Unfortunately, they were sold out of what I really wanted (pork buns). The food we did get literally made me gag. Everything tasted the same as everything else, and all of the food tasted rubbery and cold. Nothing was fresh, and the textures were terrible. I enjoy a good dim sum bakery, and most of them have to have food sitting around for a while, but this was on a different level.

We did get out of there for only about $3.50 each, so that's a plus, but it's rare that food is so bad that I don't eat it.
This place only has Styrofoam plates (no paper) and tons of other plastic, so minus points for poor environmentalism.  
The tables were grimy and small and uncomfortable. 

Like many reviewers, I wish there was a better dim sum bakery in the sunset, but I'll settle for trekking up to Good Luck Dim Sum on Clement, instead.
author: Allxie C.

description: I have found my go-to to-go dim sum spot in the Sunset District. This is not the best dim sum I've ever had, but it's decent enough. You just have to wait in line to order and hope they don't run out of what you want. My favorite things to order are the Cheung Fun (Rice Noodle Roll) and the Joong (Sticky Rice in Bamboo Leaves) which I am specifically coming back for. The Egg Tarts are okay. I speak zero Chinese so I just point to what I want, and the display windows make that process easy. Decent cheap dim sum... that's the dream!
author: Stefanie C.

description: One of my favorite to-go dim sum spots growing up in the sunset. The homemade sot milk is amazing here along with their cheap variety of dim sums. They also have porridge, Chinese donuts, and other goodies. The reason that they don't have five stars is that the food is oily but most dim sums are and the line is usually super long. They are also CASH ONLY so don't forget your money prior coming!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Tried speaking mandarin to them because I thought I would get special treatment but nope! They were mean to me as well. :( you might as well speak Latin to them and get the same amount of negligent service.

Dim sum was good though. It makes me want to get up early in the morning and go to a small to-go dim sum cafe before work..almost makes me want to.

It's cheap too! I need to try the other places in Chinatown that have higher ratings now..ahhh maybe those places will have better service and like my mandarin speaking skills..haha NOT!! I should probably learn canto.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Take out business mostly.  Good number of assorted dumplings as well as baked goods.  If they don't have what you want out in front, they'll holler in to the microphone what's desired.
author: David B.

description: Good dim sum in the sunset district
author: Peter K.

description: All in all, this is the place for standard dim sum in the Sunset.   Generally better than driving down to Chinatown and fighting the traffic and crowds.  No place really to eat so it's pure takeout.  They generally keep up the offerings throughout the entire day so they don't runout.  The baked cha siu bao is really good with generous fillings.  Siu mei and hat how are pretty generous as well and are large sized.
author: Bad News S.

description:
Food: 3/5
Price: $
Portion: 3.5/5
Appearance: 3.5/5
Presentation of food: 3.5/5
OVERALL: 3/5

Came here and tried their steamed Bbq Pork Buns because I was nearby shopping for groceries and I was starving, just needed a quick snack/bite. Even though it was near the end of the night (5-6pm) the bun was still soft and moist and the Bbq Pork was still decently flavorful. Personally when it comes to Bbq Porn Bun I'm not the biggest fan of, I feel that its the most generic item you can order from a legitimate chinese cuisine place. BUT, to my surprise it was quite tasteful.
author: Eva H.

description: Hit and miss here. They dont have the turnaround to sell everything freshly made. A mix of fresh and day old or more items. Shrimp cheung fun (flat rice noodles) were freshly made and good. Steamed char siu bao was decent. Baked char siu bao was old. Chive dumpling old. Chicken in sticky rice was fresh but so stingy with chicken and non existent Chinese sausage. Threw half of my purchase away because it was old. Bottom line is drive 5min more down to Clement st. More selection and competition for a better experience.
author: C C.

description:
One tip to dim sum bakery owners: please close your freaking doors, especially when there's a temperature difference of over 24 degrees indoors and out, else your dimsum will most likely taste like doodoo. Or kaka. Or poopoo... you get the idea.

I don't have a very distinguished palate when it comes to dimsum; I can usually only tell whether it's "good" or "bad"; "oily" or "not oily"; "flavorful" or "plain" and so forth. Most of these dim sum bakery types that I've been to in the Richmond/Sunset area have actually been pretty damn good, except for the fact that they all seem to make one critical mistake: the dimsum is never hot because the bakeries always leave their freaking doors open when it's freezing out.

Here's a few scenarios to illustrate my point.

1. I eat in at a bakery-type dimsum place with a few friends, but I'm always first in line because I speak some sort of Chinese. I wait patiently while my friends grab their food and join me at the table, but by the time they sit down, my dimsum is already cold.

2. I eat in at a bakery-type dimsum place with a few friends, and I'm first in line again. This time I sit down with my food on the table, and start scarfing them mofos down while they're still hot. My friends eventually get to the table and see that I'm already half done, bitch at me for being a douche and not waiting to eat together, and then my food turns cold while I'm being bitched at.

3. Learning from my past lessons, I tell my friends that we should this time get the food to go and eat at a friend's house. We bring the food back to his place after about 10-15 mins, the food is already cold.
Addendum: we nuke our cold siu mai in the microwave, but they don't taste the same as they do when they're comng out piping hot from the steamers.

Long story short, the dim sum here is pretty standard and they have all the usual offerings, (except coffee. i didn't see them sell coffee here.) including paigu by the bucket, but the food is ruined due to a poorly-thought out marketing technique which invites more customers but ruins the integrity of the food. WOULD SOMEONE PLEASE THINK OF THE FOOD?!
author: Scott S.

description: We've been frequenting this " hole in the wall" for at least ten years. Don't let the decor fool you.  This place has excellent dim sum. I believe they have two small tables, but the majority of their business is take out. With the crowds of nearby Dim Sum restaurants, I find it much easier to take    out, boil my own tea and have my own Dim Sum experience!  The Dim Sum is good, and the Jook is not bad for a takeout place!  Thumbs up for this establishment in the Sunset! The only negative aspect is that the lines can be long on the weekends!
author: Steven L.

description:
It was Mother's Day afternoon. I was trying to purchase some dim sum to go. As one of my favorite dim sum to go places. I had always been courteous to their staff. 
But today, I wanted to purchase some red bean cake. And the regular staff was putting the white sugar cake in my order. I informed her that I want red bean cake three times. She looks at her work station knowingly knows that the restaurant had ran out and  still want to put the white sugar cake in my order and insisted that she will sell it to me cheaper. What the hell, lady... I'm not stupid.
Honestly if you don't have an item just say you don't have it. Simple as that so I don't have to waste my time writing this. Happy Mother's Day. You just lost a customer.
author: John W.

description:
Take out dim sum in the Sunset is limited.  Consequently, its not unusual to see a line at this place.  Overall, the quality of the dim sum is average at best and the service definitely has room for improvement .  There is another take-out option in the area that I think is way better than Mongkok:  TC Pastry on Irving in the Sunset. I was at Mongkok because my favorite hangout was closed for vacation.

Here are some words of caution when you visit this establishment:  Don't let them push unwanted items on you, and make sure the math is correct when they tabulate you bill.  They have a tendency to over-charge you.
author: Jean T.

description: Jook was $2.80.  Great price, but when it was served, I realized there were a half dozen plastic containers pre-filled.  Prefer the establishments where the jook is kept heated until it's served.  Here, the temperature was lukewarm.  So, not the best.  Hai-gow (shrimp dumplings) were $3 for 4 pieces.  They were fine, but the residue of oil in the take-out box was more than other establishments.
author: Thom S.

description:
Not the best take out dim sum.  Try it if you are already in the neighborhood AND have a parking space.  Oh yeah, and you want dim sum.  It's better than driving elsewhere and trying to park.

They speak little English.  The menu is in Chinese.  There are no pictures to point to for ordering, either.
author: Debbie T.

description: THE BEST DIM SUM IN SF. Get here early for the freshest dim sum. Sunday's are always super busy.
author: I B.

description:
Dim Sum Nazi is here.
There are no fat Asian-girls in here!
I did not see them, so as *Jiveass-Milk-Tea thing.
The store is more like hole-in the wall knd.
It looks totally not wel-coming exterior and interior, so as the store clerks.
The store clerks are all Chinese old females and they all look at you with "WTF?" attitude.
But the dim sum is Good!
I think its an old style dim sum. I mean the price, flavor and the big size.
This is not a Yo Yo Taibo kind of crap.
This Mongkok style is a real thing.
Yes, Dim Sum Nazi is here.

The menu is all in Chinese, I was like wtf? but hey, that makes this dim sum more authentic kind. So as ladies work here, they look very authentic Mongkok females who don't give shit. Seriously. I was like Seinfeld, Soup-Nazi episode. I was so sure that do not become like the George Costanza, because I WANTED THE DIM SUM SO BADLY.

Oppa is Mongkok style
Mongkok style

A girl who is warm and humanle during the day
A classy girl who know how to enjoy the freedom of a few dim sum
A girl whose heart gets hotter when night comes
A girl with that kind of twist
I'm a guy 
A guy who is as warm as you during the day
A guy who one-shots his dim sum before it even cools down
A guy whose heart bursts when night comes
That kind of guy

Beautiful, Edible
Yes the Dim Sum, hey, yes the Har gow, hey
Beautiful, Edible
Yes the Dumplings, hey, yes the Shiu-mai, hey
Now let's go until the end

Oppa is Mongkok style, Mongkok style
Oppa is Mongkok  style, Mongkok  style
Oppa is Mongkok  style
Eh- Sexy Lady, Oppa is Mongkok  style
Eh- Sexy Lady 
oh oh oh oh Mongkok  style

(I think most people are done with the song, don't we all?)

Again, Dim Sum Nazi is here.
Mongkok Style kicking Gangnam Style ass good!
Oh Hell Jesus, WTF? 
It's Good Dim Sum.

*(Btw, Jiveass-Milk-Tea named by Ken K. 2 days ago.)
author: Nobu K.

description:
Seeing as how there isn't enough dim sum pickup competition in the area, that is the only reason why I ever patronize them. 

Beware as other yelp reviewers have mentioned that they will upsell and rip you off if you seem unaware of prices or what the number of pieces each order contains. I suggest checking out your goods before leaving so there aren't any surprises.
author: Peachie Y.

description:
Mongkok's menu offerings are al in chinese. no problem. the ladies are literate in english. you can also poing and ask: "how much?"

most dim sum are offered in bunches (3 for 1.80, 4/1.80, 3/2.20, etc) how many you get is also written in chinese.

sampling:
-siu mai w/shrimp(4/2.20)
huge, full of tender, juicy pork topped with shrimp                  5 stars
- shrimp cheung-rice noodle(3/1.80
thick wrapped with semitasty shrimp within, dipping sauce provided.
                                                                                                           3.5 stars
- pork bun (3/1.80)
fluffy buns with tasty, fresh bbq pork inside.                             4 stars

take outs:
-not all dim sum will be created equal or great
-4 stars for value and semitasty eats
-good bilingual service
-street parking available.
author: Victor G.

description:
Been here a few times because it's right across my favorite salon, price is relatively expensive for a small Dim Sum joint, but food quality and service are moderate and poor, they serve one of the worst sticky rice chicken I ever had, which, has nothing but rice and scrap pork meat. 

Don't waste your money here, your hard earned dollar deserves better.
author: Faust T.

description: Parking reasonable, OK prices, good selection, even later in the day.  All the standards are there.    Prices are going up though.
author: Sarah T.

description:
(See pics)

More like 3.5 stars.

Well their gigantic size dim sum was delicious and probably better if you steam them up at home. These are not the light wraps. The rice rolls were also quite good. Love the giant bay leafed sticky rice, especially in a cooler evening.

Price was quite inexpensive (usually $1.60 for 3 pieces.)

Service was fast and super nice. A good local takeout joint when you are in the neighbourhood.
author: T L.

description:
My buddy first introduced me to this quick takeout dim sum place a few years ago and I was fortunate to be reintroduced on the eve of my sister's wedding day.

We ordered several dishes and dumplings to try, but the house specialty was my favorite.  A fried potsticker of sorts, the dumpling had great authentic Chinese flavors that I've come to desperately miss while living in San Diego.  Being the first real meal on my return was a great way to start the day and the trip.

When you're in a hurry or just don't want the hassle of enjoying dim sum in a large ballroom, Mongkok is a great, affordable alternative.  If I lived in the area, I would definitely come several times a week to get my fix.

Food: 7/10

Service: 4/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 4/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Best takeout dim sum on noriega. Maybe I go here because its been walking distance my whole life but whatever, I'm loyal & I love Mongkok! 

No English menu but just point and ask whats in stuff-the ladies working there will tell you whats inside the dumplings. If you dont know what to order my go-to crowd pleasers are the siu mai, har gao, shrimp & chives, fried meat dumpling, cha siu bao (pork buns), & shrimp noodle rolls. 

For at or about $5-10 pp you can stuff your face n feel full, won't find much better of a deal than that! 

Like most take out places on Noriega they're CASH ONLY (i think thats the only english sign they have haha)
author: Siobhan T.

description:
For a quick take-out drop in, dim sum drive-by, I think this place does its job.

I wouldn't say it's amazing dim sum, but then again, I didn't have to wait in line for 30 minutes for walk through Chinatown to find it.

The dim sum is decently priced, at 3 for $1.60 for most (sui mai, ha gao etc).  It's flavorful.  Quick. Tastes good. Satisfies the craving!
author: Gloria C.

description: Good place to buy some zongzi and buns in Sunset area. The staff is not particularly nice but the food is pretty good.
author: Xaxa X.

description: Small hole in the wall dim sum take-out. Food was hot if you get it when they open to about noon. Stick with the favorites since they cook more of it throughout the morning. Dim sum taste about as good as some lesser Chinese restaurants. Price is less expensive than a sit down dim sum tea house. Negatives are the servers speak little English and parking is very difficult in morning/lunch time with $2/hour meters
author: Clifford W.

description: I stopped by on a Saturday afternoon around 4pm. There wasn't a line and contrary to many of these reviews the service was just fine. The dumplings I got were okay. The ha gao (shrimp dumplings) could have had more shrimp in it and I wish the siu mai (pork dumplings) had some shiitake mushrooms inside (it makes a big difference in taste). The wu gok (taro dumplings) was pretty tasty though.
author: Kevin C.

description: I was here just 10 minutes ago. I bought a couple items that came up to $4.72. I paid with a $10 and the lady gave me two dollars and some random coins for change. She was acting pretty sketchy as she handed me the change. I said its not the right amount and she pretended like she didn't speak English. She was understanding English just fine while I was ordering... Playing stupid. Typical for one of these holes in the wall
author: L. Y.

description: Convenient and you get in and out quick (sometimes too quick!). It can feel a little too rush because the lady taking your order will stand there impatiently waiting for you to tell them what you want when you're not even done thinking about it. I never know if they overcharge me or not cuz they mentally calculate the price in their head. Btw don't expect hello, smile or thank you!!
author: Lisa L.

description:
I definitely appreciate this place! Though it's definitely not amazing dim sum (i.e. I would not wait 30 min to get dim sum from this place), it's quite satisfying as it basically is a fast-food place for dim-sum. It definitely satisfies my craving...the place has shrimp dumplings, beef dumplings, spinach dumplings, beef meatballs, sticky rice, chicken feet, shrimp noodles and beef noodles. There's more stuff than I listed. It has two vegetarian choices - peanut dumplings and fake duck (weird! a Chinese place with fake duck?). 

I really enjoyed the sticky rice and shrimp dumplings. Though not hot and fresh, it had the enjoyable taste of yummy dim-sum leftovers. No joke! I enjoy left-overs though...anyway, the beef meatballs weren't very good.
author: Margaret R.

description: This place rocks! Their custard and red bean baked buns are sooooo good.. I don't know how they get that thin crispy layer in combination with the fluffiness of the inside. I don't know how it happened, but we walked out of there with a bag FULL of awesomeness for around $5.
author: Andrew T.

description: Come here when it's close to closing and the ladies try to sell their dimsum for cheap since its the end of the day! It's not the best tasting dimsum in town, but if you're in the neighborhood and looking for some quick cheap eats, then Mongkok dim sum is the place for you!
author: Loni K.

description:
4 Stars for the food my wife picks up
-1 Star for customer service to this ABC

So I went again to get some dim sum the other day.  GADS, I still feel like an idiot and got stuff from under the trays.  Still greasy and the helpers are just as rude.  Still got the stuff that's been saved from yesterday.  My wife goes in and gets great stuff, but for me I'll just wait until she brings it home!
author: Stefan L.

description: Definitely not good "fast" dim sum. The siu mai was kind of gross, and honestly did not taste like pork, and had this weird consistency. I don't think it was fresh. The ja lerng (chinese donut w/ rice noodles) was pre-made, so the donut was soggy, and they didn't even have the requisite sauce: hoisin and peanut. I won't return despite how close you are to me. Irving isn't THAT far.
author: Vanessa K.

description: best bang for your buck if you want cheap dim sum. think of it as the fast food for dim sum. if you crave a shew mai and bbq pork buns on the go look no further. this place has everything. quality isnt bad at all, just dont expect royalty.
author: simon c.

description: I used to come here a lot almost every other weekend to get me some takeout Dim Sum. Some of the ladies working there are rude and some are nice. But ALL of them will try to give you the bad pieces they have - broken ones, ugly lookin ones, or ones that fell out to the side!  You will need to to tell them you don't want that.  But they talk back to you and tell you that it's all the same!  Uh NO it's not, we are not stupid. Thank god I don't come here anymore!
author: Cathy M.

description:
What in the hell happened in the past year?! (Oh yeah, the economy tanked and apparently bad dim sum is being dished out here.)

Har gow = crap. 
Pork ribs = fat, greasy sauce
Noodles = wet and slimey from grease!
Dumplings = ever heard of seasoning!?
Siu mai = quite fatty pork too.
Chicken feet = how many times/how long was this cooked??  The flavor was gone, the texture became soft and fat-like instead of tender and semi-chewy.  

WTF is with this place?!  It used to be cheap and tasty...now it's just cheap, cheap, cheap and NOT good! 

Flavors = not there.  Even the soy sauce and hot sauce can't fix this mess!

Jook--they have one type (pork with preserved egg) and a large container of it.  Unfortunately, the flavors did not cook into the rice, and the rice is watery.  (Yes, it is watery rice, but this is as if someone took cooked overnight steamed rice and added water to it and pretend it is jook with any substantial flavor!)

Cash only and parking issues, still.

What a freakin'  waste of $45.00.  :-(

The only things I could even tolerate at this point are, the turnip cakes and buns.  Keep the rest of it away from me.

I could have gone to the asian market and raided the frozen foods section for this kind of crap.  (The longer I sit here and type this...the more pissed off I am about the whole thing....)
author: Fannie S.

description: Solid Local DIm Sum takeout.  Yeah, the service can be a little spotty, but when the food is fresh, it's good.   They have rice plates for only $4 and change.  Nice neighborhood spot.
author: Brian C.

description:
Let me tell you when you go into a Chinese store, bakery or a supermarket where you need to pull a number from the ticker, you have to be really aggressive. Why? Some chinese people don't follow the number system and see who comes first (some people don't follow the honesty system).

The bf stepped aside as a group of "see-lai's" (a group of women who are in their late 50's and talk really loudly at grocery stores and supermarkets) surrounded him. He said that I could make the order since I'm aggressive and I fit in well with the see-lai's minus my age (I'm young!). 

The whole number system was not in place even though I was holding a number so when a see-lai "budged" to tell the lady at the counter what kind of dimsum she wanted to go, I said in Cantonese, "hey, hey, hey, I came first so it's my turn..." She looked at me and didn't say anything. That's right. Sheesh.

We got 3 Chiu Chow Dumplings...man, just one dumpling was huge!! It was the size of my palm. They were 3 for $1.60...extremely inexpensive. They were very delicious...the vegetables were crunchy and not soggy and the meat ratio to the vegetable was 1:3 which was good. Same thing with the Siew Mai = 3 for $1.60 - they were huge! I was craving "Clay Pot" (Boot Zai) Pudding with Red bean...and they were not chewy or "bouncy" as the ones my grandma makes...it was soggy and too sweet so failed there. 

Would definitely visit Chinatown San Fran again.
author: Polly C.

description:
Since we already made the walk from my place to Safeway, the boy & I decided to explore the area to seek out places to eat in the future - or right then.

This little place is hard to see since it is sort of hidden by construction.  I got myself some dim sum for lunch since I hate waking up early to pack lunch.  I got some Lo bak go (daikon cake) which didn't have a lot of flavor, didn't have a lot of stuff in it, & it was incredibly doughy.  My mom's homemade ones are much better.  I also got some Jia leung (Chinese doughnut wrapped in rice noodles) since it's one of my favorite dim sums & I haven't had it in about 4 or 5 years.  Unfortunately I wish I hadn't gotten it & just gone another ? years missing it.  The Chinese doughnut was cold & bitter which made me suspect it was spoiled.  It was very disappointing.  The boy got a Jin deui (fried sesame seed ball) which tasted very oily & gross.  For some reason, there was a Lai wong bao (custard bun) in my stuff.  I don't know if I paid for it or not but since it was there I might as well eat it.  This bun was not the steamed kind which was interesting & it wasn't super sweet which I liked.

The items that I got are only OK at best but the prices were pretty good.  I am not too fond of eating dim sum outside of a dim sum restaurant - well at least not enough to want it often anyway - so I don't know if I'll return.  But if I ever get a craving, I wouldn't mind checking out some other items here.
author: Karen S.

description:
I've been craving take-out dim sum recently.  I stopped by Mongkok for some har gow, spareribs in black bean sauce over rice, and congee.  The total was $7.90 and I had enough food for two meals.  They're generous, and the dumplings are larger than average, so even though the prices seem average, it's actually a good deal.  Dumplings are 3 for $1.60.

* Har gow - Decent, a little salty.  They use big shrimp.  
* Congee - They only have one kind and one size (huge).  It's pork with preserved egg.  There isn't much egg or pork.  Bland.  They don't add scallions.  You can buy a fried donut though.  Good Luck Dim Sum still has the best congee for a dim sum take out place in SF.
* Pork spareribs over rice - I thought that the sparerib flavor and juice would have seeped into the long grain rice but that didn't happen. The rice was mushy and oversteamed.  They added boiled cabbage and drizzled the rice with soy sauce.  The ribs were good, a little fatty but that's to be expected.  Overall, it was just okay. 

The menu is in Chinese, so you either have to point to what you want or know what it's called.  They have a massive inventory of items - dumplings, lots of man tou (steamed buns), rice noodles with different fillings, Chinese tamales, egg rolls, sesame balls, baked sausage buns, grass jelly, turnip (or it could be taro) cake, egg custard tarts (including a white kind), chicken feet, sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf and more.  Things look greasy.  The woman who helped me does speak English but I'm not sure how well she speaks it.  You can eat it there if you want.  I've had the same items at Good Luck Dim Sum and GLDM is definitely better.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
The dim sum that stays in the steamers are always piping hot but I don't know if I will get the dim sum outside the steamers next time. They seem like they could be out for a long time and who knows if they dump out their inventory every day if it's not sold...

And they always like to sell you the "siu mai" with the shrimp on it because they can charge you more for it and they don't tell you. You have to ask for the regular ones so that they don't make you pay more.
author: Wilson T.

description:
There's not much Dim Sum Place in Noreiga Street so desperation sets in for this place. I work around this neighborhood. The older lady that works here that  has a short dark hair and has a high pitch, no class and annoying voice - bosses other younger ladies working in the front.  She is very rude and she always pushes me to buy more than i really want ( claiming she will give me a discount if I buy 4 or more of this particular dim-sum that I don't  really want ???) Does this make sense??? Is this food were talking about here or your just dumping all of this food on me that I don't care on having  cause it's either no one will buy it or it's old already?? You think I DON"T KNOW THAT!!!! 

The food especially their hotdog  bun is drowning with lard from top to the bottom of the bun! I might as well drink Crisco Oil and forget about eating the hotdog Bun cause I know the hotdog bun has more LARD than the Crisco OIl. Their food is Okay cause as I said before  no competition not much Dim Sum Take out Place around here. Their steam bun is okay, way  better than their baked barbecue pork bun , which once again is drowning with LARD!!! DIPPED IN LARD!!!

There's some Flies here also and most food don't have a cover but no worries not much Flies that a Health Department will come in and write them about. 

But one thing I have to add, I HAD STOPPED coming here for almost a year now for the simple fact that the guy that's working inside came out to take his break and sat down in one the chair and started PICKING HIS NOSE!!! That did it for me!!! No More Dim Sum there!!! I am not that DESPERATE!!! for a Dim-sum! 

Who knows maybe that black bean inside the rice cake or bun may not be a black bean after all !!!
author: myra a.

description: Sometimes I can't help but come in and get some food when I haven't had any dimsum in a long time. I am waiting in line for the next available person to take my order when I am completely ignored by the lady who takes the person after me! That was so wrong; I immediately walked out. Never coming here again to this greasy, expensive and bad customer service place.
author: Carmen L.

description: i come here early in the morning for pork shu mai, fresh potsticker, sticky rice in Lotus leaf, turnip cakes, and their baos. dim sum to-go makes life less of a hassle, the menu is in Chinese but I don't speak or read Chinese and pointing, nodding, and smiling suffices in here. Cheap, filling, delicious. hole in the wall style. My favorite. Always bring my "white" friends here to try to potstickers. By white i mean not asian or traditionally accustomed to this style of food. Come earlier for fresher :) i fux with this place
author: Shaun C.

description: That is one of my favorite to go dim sum place, their dim sum not too bad, I can't say is the best, just better than the other place in this area, I always buy the beef dumpling and chow mein (pan fried noodles), they both is my favorite, price is reasonable. But one thing I don't like is they don't give you napkins and fork until you ask them! I know they want to save money, at least you have to ask Customer want any napkins or fork? Don't let customer ask first, that is the basic services!
author: Emily W.

description: I've been here a couple of times and the food is mediocre. The service is MUCH to be desire. I like the variety here, but beware - the ladies will try to sell you some dim sum that's been sitting around. On my last visit, I waited and waited behind the only other customer in the shop. The rude ladies behind the counter just chatted away and ignored what could've been a big order. Needless to say, I left and will not be back. I'll be sending my business to TC bakery on Irving from now on.
author: Katie L.

description:
Went here on a Saturday afternoon with my mom who is a sf native.  She loves this place and now I know why!! We really only came here for the pork buns, and they were so worth it! 4 pork buns, 2 steamed and 2 baked, and two sesame buns = 4 bucks! Can not complain about that. They were all warm when we got them (noon) and so soft and the just right amount of savory and sweet. 
The place is small and there was a little line but it was a quick wait. The menu is all in Chinese but that adds character to the place. Pointing and gestures help when ordering.  But if not ask someone already there chances are they can help you out.  
Pork buns pork buns pork buns!!!
author: Meaghan S.

description:
3.5 overall.

Stumbled on this place completely by accident. Got an enormous amount of dim sum for under 16 dollars; with $5 just being a huge single order of sticky rice.

The jade chive dumplings were OK, moist but a bit odd tasting compared to other versions I've had. Not bad, but not what I expected.

The large skewered chicken balls [OK: heads out of the gutter now] were OK but not that interesting that I will order again.

The crispy bean curd rolls were very generous with the shrimp and while a touch oily were very good. We also had the shrimp rice rolls (ha chong fun) which were again very generous and good (but with take-out they don't have the very light soy-based sauce.

We also had a lightly pan browned chicken bun (guy bao) that had a chicken filling more like what you would find in an egg-roll, complete with cabbage. Not bad, but again like many of the what we tried today was just OK.

The expensive (but also generous) order of sticky rice was good, but not as full of ingredients (like lop chong) as I would like. But it was enough for two more meals, so it will be a great base for reheating.

This place is small and not well-suited for eating in. The siu my look gigantic, as do the other ones we did not try. 

Nonetheless, we could be back when on Noriega again. This place is certainly a good value.
author: Glenn H.

description:
They serve pretty decent hot-counter style dim sum for the price.  During my recent visit I got a pretty big serving of pork sparerib rice, and the shiu mai pieces were big also.  It was to the point that I wish I didn't order the shrimp rice roll also because that became too much food.

The interiors is not the cleanest, but then I shouldn't expect that from any restaurants of this type.  The counter ladies were fairly nice, which is a plus also at this type of place.
author: H K.

description:
Good place to grab take-out dim sum or if you're looking for a fast bite and don't want to deal with waiting for those dim sum carts to stroll around.  There are a 3 tables inside the small area, but they're not made for large groups.  

We ordered a few things for two people and everything came out to only $9! Such a deal! My favorite was the sticky rice wrapped in the leaves.  They offer a lot of baked buns as well.  Must come back to try their egg white tart and what looked like to be whole wheat baos.

Fast, convenient, and cheap.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I give this place 3.5 stars, but the great service made me bump my review up to 4 stars. Excellent.

My friend and I wanted to get some Chinese food and looked up places through my trusty yelp app on my blackberry bold. Little did I know that it would send me to the wrong restaurant and I ended up on the outskirts of Chinatown. So my friend and I wandered the streets since we had time to kill and ended up finding this nice hole-in-the-wall dimsum place.

We walked in and there was a steady stream of customers coming and going. My friend and I ordered various pieces of dim sum. I apologize for not knowing their names, but we ordered the shrimp wraps (or rolls?), baked hot dogs, and steamed bbq pork buns. The shrimp wraps were good, but it would have been better had I had hot sauce or some sort of dipping sauce. I suppose that was my mistake for not getting that on the side. The baked hot dog was nothing special and I feel like there was too much bread and not enough meat. The baked hot dog was definitely my least favorite...probably because it's the most Americanized piece of dim sum there? The steamed bbq pork buns were good, but again, would have been better with some hot sauce or vinegar/soy sauce dipping sauce.

All in all, this place was a great find and had great service (who, not to sound ignorant, were very English friendly). The prices were MORE THAN reasonably and I will definitely be paying this place a visit the next time I am in the bay area and craving some dim sum.
author: David U.

description:
I love this place. It's around the corner from where I live and I stop by to grab a quick bit all the time. The place is rather small. They have a few small tables and one large round table so I wouldn't recommend dining in. However, it is a great place to take out food if you are looking for a good place to take-out lunch/dinner or just entertaining a party or get-together at home. 

The service is FAST, the prices are CHEAP, and the portions are HUGE. I always get their congee with pork and preserved eggs, chicken rice in lotus leaf, BBQ pork buns, and pork spareribs over rice. Everything is pretty tasty but these are my favorites. Try it! You would not be disappointed.

The only con I have is that this place is cash only but that's almost every asian restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Ellen W.

description: Good Saturday dim sum. No English so you have to point but quite cheap and tasty.
author: Ddc C.

description:
I used to come here all the time for dim sum. I stopped coming here when they had to shut down because of some health violation. I was scared to come back.

The ladies can be a bit rude/mean but that's the price you have to pay for yummy dim sum.

One time I was a buying a TON of different dim sum and I brought my own tupperware. The lady was totally ok with it.


Ok so I can't read Chinese but I swear they always charge me different prices. Whatever, it's only a couple of cents. 

Parking is a bitch since you're in the other "Chinatown". 

Watch out for the other people who will cut in front of you to order. 

One time I found a hair in my food. Gag!

CASH only

Big Fat Boy Sized fresh dim sum. Why wouldn't you pay more for a siu mai with a shrimp on top? Smaller sizes available for white boy buns and Chinese tamales. You want someone to kiss your ass in a dim sum place, better go to Yang Sing on Spear St. where you can pay 3X the amount, pay 15 bucks for parking, sit with the nouveau rich, have your water glass filled and no one will pick their nose, at least in front of you.  I have never had a problemo here and joke with the ladies who work from 5AM to 7PM or longer like every other recent Asian immigrant.  So go in speak up, point at what you want, pay, and get out. The ladies have work to do.  Headed there now.
author: Tim L.

description: A  friend of mine took his wife for an anniversary lunch. My friend's wife found a CIGARETTE BUTT in her dumpling. When shown to the waiter, he offered to give the couple coupons for their next visit. Of course, they turned down the coupons since they weren't EVER coming back.
author: Holly F.

description:
There are several options one can partake in with regards to Cantonese style dim sum. 

First, there's the fancy sit down restaurant where you get charged per person for a pot of tea (with complementary hot water refills), with or without the push cart experience by naggy pushy at times clueless older ladies at some places (which make you wonder if some of them work on commi$$ion in addition to the child labor hourly rate$ they are getting from the A$IAN Cheapne$$ restaurant owner$). Depending on the location, quality, and prestige of this type of restaurant, this will be the more pricer option.

The second one is of course the el cheapo nitty gritty frozen and microwaveable variety, available at your finest Asian supermarket (Amoy and Doll brands come to mind with a myriad of other selections only for the bold & the brave). Great for post Asian clubbing munchie stoners (that is if you're not too stoned to operate a microwave). This one is I suppose the only "24 hour" solution (unlike in Taipei where there ARE 24 hour dim sum restaurants, none of them I hear are any good or authentic, but available nonetheless and better than the frozen crap we have).

The third one is somewhere in between, and for SF city proper, that is the smaller Chinatown like shops that make and steam/fry/bake/cook their own dim sum in house and sell them to-go only. It's not restaurant quality, but sure beats being a stoner munchie or a munchie stoner resorting to TV dinner style snacking. Luckily you can find these kinds of shops in the Richmond and of course scattered places across the Sunset.

And Mongkok Dim Sum on Noriega, at least based on my last take-out experience with them years ago, has proven to be a reliable and very affordable means.of dimming the sum.

My memory is mostly failing on me, but I've stuck with the basics and the classics from MDS (from shrimp dumplings, shiu mai, chicken feet/phoenix claws, fried daikon cake, chive dumplings, rice noodle rolls with beef, various dim sum desserts etc), and they've come through for me and my stomach a lot more than flakey friends or unreliable family members.

Again decent, great value, a tad bit unrefined and perhaps a wee bit Americanized, but not uber restaurant pimp class.

Come early well before the lunch crowds and the vicious meter maids hit, coz that double parking fine to run inside MDS buying to go might end up costing as much as a lunch at Koi Palace with crab XLB.

And now for the completely useless and unrelated part of the review.

The name Mongkok derives from an area in Hong Kong, pronounced Wong Gok (used to be called Argyle in English, then reverted back to Mongkok after British rule ended in 97), that very loosely translates to "very busy and packed point". It is THE most happening place to be for youngsters, hipsters, and maybe their version of Yelpers & Facebookers. Lots of cool shops for the ladies, guys, ranging from pop culture, fashion, electronic gadgets, running shoes, snacks, desserts, restaurants, CD and media stores, arcade malls that might house some counterfeit bootleg DVD-rs of movies and video games, trinkets and the ilk. 

Some areas of Mongkok used to be shall we say, rather rough and tough. The scene of a lot of after hours gang related activity, where competing gangs may occassionally bust out a lead pipe or a knife and do some live man to man butchery. And of course the red light districts (although I'm told many have cleaned up as a result of government crackdowns, but that is still around to some extent or moved to the outer edges) where many a local man roam the grounds in search of love for rent amongst locals, Chinese from China, Russians, SE Asians and whatever exotic breeds float their boats. Part of the crime of course run by the gangs.

So yes, Mongkok has been fondly referred to as "Mein Cock" amongst the luxurious pleasure seekers of the night. And no they are not looking to dim sum, but to dim dong. No wonder Ed M commented with a "tee hee" on the name in his review.

example of usage between two pleasure seeking bromantic comrades:

Hong Konger dude #1: "Hey dude, what shall we do tonight?"
Hong Konger dude #2: "How about we go poke some balls?" (snooker that is)
Hong Konger dude #1: "My girlfriend is playing mah jong tonight all night. How about we go to Mein Cock!"
Hong Konger dude #2: "Awwww yeah baby! Sounds good! Let's do that after poking balls. I'm getting the extra topping of 5 star ice fire BJ treatment!" (alternating between mouthfuls of hot tea and ice water)
Hong Konger dude #1: "Yes let's make this a Poking night! Poke some balls, then poke OUR balls. They don't call me the Bone Joint (Massage Parlor) Master for nothing!"
author: Ken K.

description:
I don't think the dim sum here is all that bad. It's close by the house and the line moves rather quickly. There is a variety in the selection and are all very savory. 

I refer the bf (who's from san mateo) here when his family wants some dim sum. He likes coming here too and can pick up boxes full of food for a great price.
author: Maria B.

description: THE BEST SHRIMP SHIU MAI IN THE WORLD. only that though. dont waste your time on har gows.
author: kim w.

description:
Seriously, if this wasn' t the only take out dim sum joint in the Noriega area, I would NOT come here. But unfortunately, this is the only one around. 

I usually go to Irving's dim sum joints. 

The food here is bland and non authentic. I am surprise of the good review these place gets.

The owners act nice but always give you the left overs and bad pieces of dim sum. The ones on the bottom and the one that does not look appetizing at all. The only way they will give you decent pieces of dim sum is when they HAVE to because there is no bad ones there OR when you demand and point to that specific piece that you want like all the Chinese ladies. But then again, we are all civilized beings, so we just stand there and let them give you whatever shit piece of dim dum they please.

And this happened more than once! ALMOST every dam time!

I dont believe this is the way that they should do business. And it's not only because of the " you are white" thing. They pull that shit on anyone and everyone.

Bottom line is, compared to other real genuine dim sum shops, this place is a joke in terms of the food quality and dim sum authenticity. 
If you know real dim sum, you know what I am talking about.

Pass this place please.
author: U L.

description: If you like pork siu mai this is your place. I like that they top their pork siu mai with a piece of shrimp. Very tasty.
author: Aj S.

description: Mongkok  Dim Sum is inexpensive because the dim sum is of low quality. The meat fillings are not always fresh and the wrappers are sometimes dried out and crusty.  If you go early in the morning, you will be sold leftovers from the day before that has been reheated.
author: Lucky L.

description:
I love this little place.

My parents always come here to buy dim sum on days when my mom is too lazy to cook... Or if the refrigerator have nothing left to make a meal out of. 

Now, whenever I have cravings, I'll come by to pick some up.

Most things here are three items per order (three ha gows would be one order). And if they're like five left of one particular item, they'll hook you up with all five for the price of three! Sweet deal!

They make my shrimp cheung fun just the way I like it.. And I love the soy sauce that comes with it!

As always, make sure you make some tea to go with your greasy dim sum.
author: Nance W.

description:
If you're searching for good decent dim sum for take-out in the Sunset, this is one of your choices.  I've come here in the past a bit for Sunday brunches.  The siu mai, vege.bean curd roll wraps, pork buns, fung jow, are all good.  Wait in line since it can get busy morning times.
If you want to dine in -- then I suggest walking 2 blocks down to the other corner place.
author: Eric Y.

description:
Their crispy shrimp rolls are the best thing here, next best would be the chicken dumplings, chicken skewers, egg tarts.

Prices are definitely more expensive than china town as expected because of the higher overhead cost.

So why 3 stars and not 4?

I keep getting different bills at the every time I come in. Sometimes it's dirt cheap, sometimes they just decide to tack on a few dollars. And I know it's not their closing time prices because this happens in the mourning.
author: Keit K.

description: Decent cheap dimsum. Not the best dimsum I ever had, but it meets my basic standards for quick grab-and-go dim sum. They could have abit more variety, but for the price, I can't complain.
author: Heather M.

description: Came here for some quick To-Go Dim Sum in the morning. My friends love the food. But I had better Dim Sum.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Recently came to Mongkok of  2438 Noriega Street  to buy some of my most favorite dim sum items but it has been a while since, I have not been here to buy some of the dim sum items from MongKok... Until last week, I finally had the chance to come back to MongKok Dim Sum.... The dim sum items which, I have bought from Mong Kok were really good and tastly... The dim sum items which, I have bought was a big sized Sticky Rice with beef & pork wrapped in a lotus leaf and two types of Siu Mai's one of the Siu Mai's was a regular and the other siu mai which, I dont see to often at some Dim Sum places that sells this kind of Siu Mai that has shrimp on top of it... Mong Kok had it and I bought it immediately they had alot of other good tasting dim sums... I only went for the kind that I really wanted which was the big sized stickly rice with beef & pork wrapped in a lotus leaf and the two types of Siu Mai's one regular Siu Mai and Shrimp Siu Mai which all that I have bought tasted really goooooood!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This is the one place that I will be back again to buy their Awesome Dim Sum's from MongKok Dim Sum of 2438 Noriega Street in San Francisco's Sunset Area!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

HIP HIP HOORAY 

HIP HIP HOORAY 

THIS IS MY 200TH YELP REVIEW!!!!!
author: William B.

description:
The dim sum here is pretty good for take-out...

The size of their pork dumplings are almost the size of my fist! And they are quite tasty though a bit on the greasy side..

As for their baked pork buns, I find that the meat on the inside is a little too wet for my taste...

But for a quick dim sum fix, this is the place to go!
author: Jade B.

description: The dim sum was alright. The place is small. The floors a little slippery. Friendly staff.
author: Colin P.

description: I am a born and raised San Franciscan. I grew up with dim sum. This is definitely NOT the place for good dim sum.The deep fried fare is much greasier than in most other places and the sponge cake is not even close to being good. I kept telling the woman that I wanted one of this item and one of that item, but she kept on insisting that I buy a full order. She even sneaked one order by and I only discovered it once I had reached my destination. The service was horrible and the food was not even good.
author: Oyabun D.

description: 5 stars for the best baked BBQ pork buns. I guess I'll take a star off for the other food they offer. The other dim sum dishes are okay but if you come here, try a pork bun - you won't be disappointed.
author: C K.

description:
This is a take-it-to-go kinda place. The food that comes out is good, and filling, but not necessarily tasty. Some of it is really good. Some of it is really bad. But not everything is consistent unfortunately, so you take a luck of the gamble on the dish you order. I tend to love the har gow, and the rice noodle dishes. I pretty much get the chicken lotus leaf tamale everytime I go here, and the congee is pretty awesome. 

This place is safe, and I've never gotten sick here. Unfortunately there are others who have, and I sometimes wonder if it's because I'm just relatively lucky here, or they just all have bad luck. It's one or the other. Just look out for the siu mai. I've actually never had a siu mai from any restaurant that was good, only because they either undercook it, overcook it, or jell it in fat. This place tends to had a lot of fat that comes free with your siu mai. Some love it, I tend not to.

Overall, this place is decent, the prices are decent, and the service is just decent. So I'll come here again and again, but it's not a place I go out of my way for.
author: Clinton L.

description: mediocre dim sum take out. the food is alright. but of course, we've all had better. I wish the other dim sum take out spot (used to be down the block, where the pho place is) was still around instead. service sucks and I hate the fact that those ladies always try to push me to get something else. NO means NO, damn it! btw, make sure they don't overcharge you. they tend to do that to people who don't really speak Chinese. I've seen it several times already.
author: Ann T.

description: One of my favorite to-go dim sum places! I came here over the weekend to grab a quick dim-sum lunch. I love little dim sum places like these, cause you can get yummy dim sum quickly without having to wait in long lines, and fighting for tables. We tasted a little bit of everything! Most pieces are 3 for $1.60 (noodle rolls and buns are extra) - and you don't have to get the same 3 things! You can get 1 piece of this, and 1 piece of that, and combine it together. They have a good variety of everything here too: shrimp dumplings (haw gow), pork dumplings (sui mai), dumplings with scallops, dumplings with mixed veggies and pork, turnip cake, eggtarts, bbq pork buns, variety of steamed buns, beefballs, chicken sui mai's,  sticky riced wrapped in lotus leaf, pot stickers, jook,  rice noodle rolls, etc. Def. a good place to grab a quick bite of dim sum!
author: Betty S.

description: I get the spare rib(?) or chicken rice.  It's like $3-4?  Super worth it.  It's cheap, good and filling.  It has rice(w/optional soy sauce), chicken or spare rib, and choy.
author: Melanie W.

description:
Umm, I thought this place might be good, seeing as how I was the only white guy getting food here and the only white guy I have seen going here ever.  I was wrong.  The shu mai, as Ed has said is waaay too big.  So big in fact that the beef in mine was still very pink in the middle.  Not tight.  Obviously I was at a disadvantage only being able to speak English and Spanish so asking the ingredients of certain dumplings and buns was out of the question.  The first try went something like:
Me:  "Is that pork?"
Her:  "You want four?"  
Which sounded like:  "it's pork"
followed by her placing 4 in a bag.

I enjoyed a few bites of my pork buns and this flaky sweet beefy filling type thing, but that was about it.
author: Charley B.

description:
I appreciate this place for being so close to home.  There really ought to be more dimsum places in the Sunset.

Mongkok offers a quick fix for dimsum cravings.  Decent shiu-mai, however the  har gow is lacking.  Stuffed tofu is delicious, but they rarely have it available.  

The items are often greasy or on the verge of spoiling- especially items with shrimp in it.   The servers will push food on you and employ high pressure sales tactics-- as in bagging up items you already  refused.

My advice, know what you want and be firm in ordering.  Do not hesitate to say "no" when the servers offer you something else.

Also, know how much everything costs so you don't get ripped off.  The signs are all in Chinese but know most items are 3 for $1.60.  

I'd opt to find my dimsum elsewhere, but I crave them too often and this place makes decent shiumai, stuffed tofu and egg white tarts.

CASh only.  Terrible parking.
author: B B.

description:
LOVE IT! I always get my dim sum here now...

No credit cards = ( 

The shu mai...has shrimp on top of it...reallly good, but the har gow are just alright...not the best...but fairly good. The jook is decent, plain....with duck egg...

On weekends, be sure to go early...to beat the crowds....
author: Alison N.

description:
This place is quite discrete and for people who don't know...you probably would drive past it and not notice anything...but little did you know this place serves probably the best dim sum I've ever enjoyed in my existence.  I loved it.  This place serves the best dim sum for a lazy ass hungover Sunday morning breakfast.  My only urks about the place is...parking sucks, especially on a Sunday morning when everyone is at church or shopping for groceries or around this area shopping.  And there is usually a line OUT THE DOOR.  Not that its a bad thing that the food is so good that people would wait for it...but it just is another minor inconvenience we have to encounter once in a while.  

I don't know the names of anything that is served, and I usually let my friend pick it out since he knows.  The thing I LOVED the best are the deep friend taro, meat and onion dumpling things wrapped in paper.  Oooh that is excellent.  Try it.  Ahh...good stuff.
author: Christina A.

description: Take out dim sum that is generous and semi-cheap.
author: Patrick C.

description:
You'll like it if you: don't mind the quality of dim sum and just want an MSG  fix.

Since SF has so many good dim-sum take out joints, this place just doesn't cut it.  Maybe I just ordered the wrong items.  I had my staple Sunday morning treats:  Chicken Siu Mai, Lotus-wrapped sticky rice chicken and Fun-Gor.  The Siu Mai's were HUGE - i give them that... but very starchy and after 10 minutes, my mouth was craving for water.  (lotso MSG??)  Will need to venture again for another dim-sum take-out place :o(
author: Nutmeg Y.

description:
Had a very late lunch here today. 

Of the things we had, the pork spareribs with bok choy over rice was delish and highly recommended. 

The dim sum, like someone else mentioned, was not juicy hot and steamy, seemed like it had been sitting around for a little bit. I'm wondering if it would be better to go during mad rush hour to ensure you get it super freshly cooked. 

I found the counter ladies to be friendly and helpful enough. I'd say it was more than competent dim sum, but nothing super special, at a bargain price ($8 for two), and would definitely eat here again if in the neighborhood.
author: dana l.

description:
SF's dim sum and chinese food has been slacking, but this place has a few good dishes that make it the pros in those orders.  I love the "boot zhai gou" which is this gooey, chewy, flat "mochi-like" sweet snack.  YUM!  I also like the "bak tong go" which is a white desert.  DOUBLE YUM!!!

My fav, something you have to order when you're here, is the baked bbq pork buns!  It's the best in the city!  And it's not overpriced like some places!  Give this place a chance and you won't regret it!
author: Cristina L.

description: Food quality wise, I think this place deserves a 3.5. It's not the highest quality and freshest dimsum, but it's convenient,cheap, and has a good selection to choose from. I love coming here to pick up lunch for two or three that will cost me about 15 bucks total. Last time, I got the eggtarts and the WHITE eggtarts :D (healthier and just as good). I'm a huge fan of their huge shumais and the sticky rice bun. AHH so good :D will be returning for more and more.
author: Bonita C.

description: Came here the other day with my Mom.  We order a few things, har gow, sui mi, baked BBQ pork bun, etc. After paying the lady behind the counter  she took my order and then proceeds to stick it in the microwave...huh? What's up with that?! Other places have it hot enough right off the steamer. I went back to the table and I told my Chinese mom they're "nuking" the food. She just looked at me, like, "What?!"   So after a good couple of mins. (no kidding) in the microwave I ended up just getting a plate of rubbery "bit of heart"!  Not again, there's so many other places where they don't reheat your food in the microwave!
author: Shirley M.

description: Cheap and tasty Dim Sum! It is a good thing I only order char siu bao and shumai because the menu is in Chinese. I can'tt even read American. So I just point.
author: Kevo M.

description: so the boyfriend is shouting with a hangover 'dim sum', 'dim sum!'  ok, need something close by. he said he's been here before and it was ok. well, sad to say i probably won't be back. we did, though, get a HUGE amount of dim sum for $22. and i mean, practically 1 order of everything we saw *it was the alcohol talking!* Everything was eh. way too oily, greasy. limp. nothing had life to it. oh and the scallop dumpling she pushed on us, was gross, one bite and a fishy taste, spit it right out.
author: Abigail W.

description: We come here if we're too lazy to go out and get dim sum on sundays.  It's cheap, decent tasting and fast.  So far we don't have any complaints about the food. Seems like other reviews could say otherwise.
author: LittleBird 8.

description: This is probably a 4 star for me but their baked ca shao bao(pork buns) is probably one of the best I've had. Of course, this depends on how freshly baked it is but what makes it so good is the lean meat and the wetness of the their stuffing. I'm a big fan of gravy! Also, most places will stick in a lot of leftover fatty pork which can be pretty nasty and poor quality. The other dim sum dishes they have here are just so-so, but you should definitely try their pork buns!
author: Jonathan T.

description: My family picks up dim sum from Mongkok all the time. It's not much of a dine- in shop, but always perfect for to go/ take home. There's definitely variety here, and the shop is always super clean. You can expect the dim sum to have good, fresh fillings at very reasonable prices. It's NOT the BEST dim sum I've ever had, but for its prices, and for a neighborhood take- out dim sum place, it's definitely above average and hits the spot every time.
author: Carmen L.

description:
I seriously don't understand all the negative comments. 

Sure the food is not top of the line -- but consider the price that you are paying and and the convenient location for Sunset residents, there's not much to complain about.  

It's clean, they offer variety, and did I mention that it's cheap? 

It is my good old reliable.
author: E L.

description: This place is ok if you're looking for big portion of dim sum. The taste and the price is just OK. It's not really cheap compare to Clement St. And it's almost the over dim sum place located in outer Sunset so it's always packed. Most of the time you get a little discount when you order more. But that piss my wife sometime bcuz she can't eat that much.
author: Jason L.

description: The prices here are more reasonable than at other places but as they say, you get what you paid for.  It's not high quality dim sum.  Only a few items here I would recommend. Their egg rolls are pretty good, egg custard, siu mai and chicken buns.  The rest are so-so, but there's not a dim sum place in the neighborhood that opens so early and they close late too.  The Asian lady employees hurry you along but if you frequent the place often, they recognize you and give you nicer treatment.  It's not bad food to pick up for co-workers who don't care much about the quality of the food (my co-workers eat anything. Heck, they didn't pay for it).    There's a couple of small tables if you chose to dine in, but it's limited.
author: Ry T.

description: It's decent priced dim-sum. Nothing special out in the Sunset. I just think that it has a funny name...
author: Michael C.

description:
this place is "ok", not the best dim sum by any stretch of the imagination, but acceptable if you're in the Sunset and itching for some take out dim sum - what other choice have you got?

the problem is that this place serves LEFTOVER OVERNIGHT dim sum.  know how you can tell?  the skin on the dimsum looks like it's about to fall off...because when you reheat it, the skin was already cooked and soft to begin with...the 2nd go around will literally cause the skin on most dim sum to fall apart.  my worst experience was when i bit into the dim sum and the core was still cold!

so I have a beef with them charging me full price and selling me leftovers.   so hint:  don't go buy their dim sum first thing in the morning...you've been warned!
author: Astroboy L.

description:
Shu mai is made with pork, not beef.

My family often orders take out dim sum here since we are cheap.  One can get quite a bit of food here for a good price.  With this in mind, I don't expect miracles and you can get better (and more expensive) dim sum at most regular sit down dim sum restaurants.   

With regards to ordering, I let my dad do it.  I could definitely see issues with this place if you dont speak Cantonese here.  

Also, a couple years back someone spread a dirty rumor that one of the owners of this place had contracted SARS.  That was funny, since it actually hurt their business until people forgot about it.  Mean though; they must have pissed someone off really bad...
author: Jeff H.

description: I ordered a massive quantity of food from this place. Definitely overzealous with the pointing. I wasn't disappointed either, it was tasty and super cheap which makes it a winner in my book. It wasn't the best quality dim sum I've ever had, but for the price I'm sold. I also liked the staff and appreciated their humoring my pronunciation.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
i usually go here when i want dimsum thats cheap, fast and close to my house.  they get that fourth star because they give you free stuff when you go around closing time. 

i wouldnt recommend eating inside ....
author: Doug ..

description: Good dim sum for take-out.  I wouldn't recommend eating inside since it's very small place.
author: Stacey L.

description:
their takeout dimsum is large and cheap and of better than average quality.

enough said.  come here, and grab a few boxes of stuff, pay a few bucks, and leave happy.
author: Jason J.

description: Eh.. It's edible but definately isn't the best. They have long lines often, that stretches out the door. Sometimes you just know that you got leftover dim sum from the day before.
author: Katherine C.

description: BEEN GOING HERE SINCE I WAS A KID! ITS THE BEST!u have to go before 2pm for the best variety but where else can you spend $10 and feed 4 people? plus its soooooo tastey
author: Laura S.

description: totally agree with other review on lousy service but okay food at low prices.  staff speaks minimal english and give the same subpar service even if you speak their language.
author: Kl C.

description: I went here after class one time, and was pleasantly surprised. I have been to many Chinese bakeries in my lifetime, and I know what to expect and not to expect. Things not to expect: great service and decorative atmosphere. What I do expect is for the food items be cheap and delicious. The dim sum items were really good here. The siu mais particularly were really good and are huge. The baos were pretty good too. The amount of money that cost to fill me up here was way less than if I were to go to Micky Ds.
author: Hilland C.

description: we practically order out from here every week.  dim sum is good and tasty.   thumbs up!
author: n y.

description: There are far better and cleaner dim sum places in the city.  This is one of those inexpensive dim sum places where you order at the counter which makes it ok for an impulse quickie dim sum run, but it's ultimately dissatisfying because it's either too greasy or too dried out.  They do, however, have these interesting egg white egg tarts that I haven't found elsewhere.
author: Raz R.

description: This place was recommended to me by a co-worker of mine.  Their foods is in big portions.  They have two sizes of their cha-siu bows.  The large ones are enough for me for a lunch, and they also make small ones, just as stuffed with the meat.  They're not skimpy on that, that's for sure.  All their dim-sum dumplings are great.  Yes, they have HUGE siu mai dumplings.  They more than most dim sum houses have.  What's my favorite is the naw-mei faan.  Which in English is called Glutinous Rice, or simply Sticky Fried Rice.  That too is a couple of meals in itself.  I like it here, and they're not so rude.  I know what I want, I may not be able to say it in Chinese, as my Chinese is very slim to none...But I know what specific things are because I grew up eating my favorites.  And if you're lucky enough you can get front door parking.  Otherwise, you may need to park up the street in the residential areas.  It's worth a check if you like variety.
author: Cheryl N.

description: i consider dim sum the perfect food! cheap, portable, and variable. i know my way around a steamy dim sum exhibit and can tell the difference between a baked and steamed bbq pork bun from 500 meters. mongkok's dim sum was cold with indistinguishable ingredients that lacked freshness and texture. most of my dissatisfaction came from the fact that everything we ordered was COLD! cold dim sum, thats a crime in my book .the fact that this place has more stars than HAPPY BAKERY on Irving is disturbing.
author: Andrew F.
